article.title: Design and Implementation of Concurrent C0

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the `wait($c)` function call on line 17 of Figure 1 do?
choices: Sends a signal to the process providing on channel `$c` to terminate.
Waits for the process providing on channel `$c` to close the channel.
Checks if channel `$c` has any messages available to receive.
Blocks the current process until it can receive a value from channel `$c`.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the `$q = elem(x, $r)` statement on line 21 of Figure 2 achieve?
choices: It modifies the existing queue element to store the new value `y`.
It creates a new process to handle the tail of the queue starting from element `x`.
It replaces the head of the queue with a new element containing `x`, with the tail remaining as `$r`.
It closes the current channel `$q` and opens a new channel with the updated queue.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3e, why does forwarding involve sending a special message instead of simply concatenating the buffers of `$q` and `$r`?
choices: Concatenating the buffers could lead to type errors since the session types of `$q` and `$r` might be incompatible.
The direction of communication on `$q` and `$r` is different at the time of forwarding, making concatenation ineffective.
Concatenation would require locking both channels simultaneously, potentially leading to deadlocks.
Sending a special message is more efficient than concatenating potentially large channel buffers.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the width of the session type in Figure 4 signify?
choices: The maximum number of concurrent client processes that can interact with the ATM.
The maximum number of messages that can be stored in the channel buffer at any given time.
The maximum number of consecutive deposits or withdrawals a client can perform without receiving a response.
The maximum number of different operations supported by the ATM protocol.
